entry.title: SSH-Notes
entry.content:
Table of Contents
  • Background
  • Authentication
    • Passwords andÂ Keys
    • Handshake

Background

  1. Secure Shell lets you securely connect to remote servers. You connect using an account that exists on the remote server. Once youâ€™ve connected youâ€™ll be dropped into a shellÂ session.

  2. The computer you connect from is the â€œlocalâ€ or â€œclientâ€ computer. The computer you connect to is the â€œhostâ€ or theÂ â€œserverâ€.

  3. When youâ€™re connected to the server using SSH, any commands you input from the client are sent securely and privately (through a â€œtunnelâ€) to the remote computer, where the commands areÂ executed.

  4. SSH is implemented using the client-server model. The server must be running a small app to listen for SSH connections. This kind of app is called a daemon (pronounced day-mon). For SSH to work, the host must be running the SSH daemon. The SSH daemon listens for connections on a specific port (22), authenticates connections requests, and (if the connection request is approved) it will spawn the correct environment. The correct environment is a terminalÂ session.

  5. The client (the computer you connect from) must be running an SSH client, which is a small app that can communicate using the SSH protocol. (A protocol is a set of rules.) It needs to be able to receive information about which host to connect to, which user to connect as and which credentials to use when trying toÂ connect.

Authentication

Passwords andÂ Keys

  1. Clients authenticate using passwords or keys. Passwords are less secure than keys. Keys are very secure. You can also connect using no authentication by specifying a particular IP address IÂ think.

  2. Passwords are encrypted, and are conceptually familiar, but can (and will) be brute forced. There are tools that will block repeated attempts or block/allow authentication attempts from particular IPÂ addresses.

  3. SSH keys using public and private (or secret) key pairs and are very secure. Keys are generated in pairs. The public key can be shared freely without concern. The secret key must be kept as secure and secret as aÂ password.

  4. To authenticate using a key pair, the client must have both keys (a key pair) on their computer. The server must have the public key in a file called authorized_keys. If the server has the private key then something has gone wrong and you should beÂ alarmed.

The server stores the public keys of users who can connect as a particular user in the file ~/.ssh/authorized_keys. The file contains a list of public keys, one public key on eachÂ row.

  1. The default location to store the public key on the remote server is in the users home folder in a subdirectory called .ssh/authorized_keys. The full path would be ~/.ssh/authorized_keys

Handshake

  1. When a client wants to connect to a server using SSH, it tells the server which public key to use. The server then checks in the authorized_keys file for the publicÂ key.

  2. A unique session ID is generated and shared between the client andÂ server.

  3. If the server has the same public key that the client sent when it began the connection attempt, the server generates a random string and encrypts it using the public key. This random string can only be decrypted using the private (secret) key associated with the publicÂ key.

  4. The server sends the encrypted string to the client. The client decrypts it using the secret key and combines the original random string with the session ID. The client then hashes the combined string and sends the hash back to theÂ server.

  5. The server already has the hash of the string combining the original random string and the session ID. If the hash from the client matches the hash on the server, the server can be sure that the client has the privateÂ key.

entry.content:
Table of Contents
  • Background
  • Razor

Background

Chezmoi seems to be dotfiles management for power users. Until a few days ago, when I realised Iâ€™d massively broken a lot of things, Iâ€™d been putting my dotfiles in a version controlled directory and using a shell script to generate symlinks in my homeÂ directory.

This had worked really well for several years. Itâ€™s a great system for maintaining dotfiles on a single machine. But itâ€™s not robust or flexible enough for managing multiple machines or multiple operatingÂ systems.

Also, itâ€™s not just files that sit in $home anymore, I need to track configuration files that live in other places too1.

I needed something more robust and flexible than generating symlinks from a bashÂ script.

Razor

I think I read somewhere that when purchasing a new appliance you should buy the cheapest you think you can get away with, and if that doesnâ€™t work then get the best you can afford. Moving from a custom bash script to Chezmoi is an example of this. My custom bash script was the most basic approach, and it broke badly. Chezmoi seems like the most heavy duty tool for dotfiles management I couldÂ find.

For example, I think Iâ€™m able to encrypt my files using 1Password or similar. I can use Jinja templates to create scripts for different scenarios. I donâ€™t even know what that means at the moment. Iâ€™ve only scratched the surface but Iâ€™m happily managing dotfiles across different machines and updating/modifying them safely. Chezmoi (aliased to cm) is free and OSS so Iâ€™m confident itâ€™ll be â€œmyâ€ tool for the next few decades. Iâ€™m happy to invest a couple of hours to learn a few new habits and iron out a few wrinkles2.

OneÂ Question

I donâ€™t understand why chezmoi cd creates a new shell in order to jump into the Chezmoi directory. Why not simply cd into the Chezmoi directory? Whatâ€™s the advantage/necessity of a newÂ shell?

You have to remember to exit after youâ€™ve done whatever you went there to do, but my habit is to cd or z ... I guess itâ€™s nice to exit and then immediately go back to where ever you were before, but there are other ways of doing that - you could write the current directory to an environment variable. It seems unnecessarilyÂ complex.

CommandÂ Reference

  1. Type cm instead of chezmoi: alias cm="chezmoi"
  2. Show which files have changed: cm status
  3. Start tracking a file: cm add
  4. Update a file, add the file again: cm add ..
  5. Edit tracked version of file: cm edit - donâ€™t think Iâ€™m going to use this, Iâ€™d rather edit the source file, test it, and then update using cm add ..
  6. Differences between local version and tracked versions: cm diff - this tells me which files I need to cm add again. This feels clunky and I suspect there is a better workflow. Parsing git style diff files isÂ horrible.
  7. Clobber local version with the tracked version: cm apply
  8. Dry run and see diff between local version and tracked version: cm -nv apply
  9. Pull the latest changes from your repo and apply them: cm update
  10. Remove a file:
    • Create .chezmoiremove in the sourceÂ directory
    • chezmoi apply --remove --dry-run --verbose
  11. List of managed files: cm managed
  12. List of unmanaged files: cm unmanaged

Links

  2. Happily, it seems like the amount of time required to learn or become familiar with a new tool is decreasing. I guess this is to be expected as experience increases but nonetheless itâ€™s gratifying to realise.

entry.title: I Leaked Credentials Onto A Public GitHubÂ Repo
entry.content:
Table of Contents
  • Donâ€™t post secrets to public GitHubÂ repositories.
  • Background
  • TheÂ hack
  • Remediation
  • Questions
  • Study
  • Comments

Donâ€™t post secrets to public GitHubÂ repositories.

I made this mistake a while ago, and in the interests of openness and learning from others, Iâ€™d like to describe what happened. Maybe itâ€™ll help others avoid the mistake, and maybe Iâ€™ll learn something from any conversation this articleÂ generates.

Background

Using Google Cloud Platform (GCP), Iâ€™ve been doing some work across multiple compute instances. Thankfully, the work wasnâ€™t business critical or on production systems. My account was isolated away from the rest of theÂ business.

As the number of servers I was working with increased, I realised I needed to begin using some tools to automate server setup. This lead me to begin using Ansible, and once Iâ€™d cobbled together a working playbook I pushed my Ansible project to my GitHub accountâ€¦ And accidentally leaked the key for an account Iâ€™d beenÂ using.

TheÂ hack

Within a couple of minutes of pushing the repository to GitHubÂ I:

  • Made the repositoryÂ private.
  • Stopped tracking the keys in git and removed them from the cache git rm -r --cached .
  • Received an email from Google saying theyâ€™d found leakedÂ credentials.

OK, close call. The secret was leaked for less than 5 minutes. On my obscure personalÂ GitHub.

I thought there was nothing to worry about.. But then I noticed some activity in theÂ console.

Compute instances were being created, I could see the list growing rapidly. Over the next few minutes 195 compute instances and disks were being created, each with a unique name in zones across the world. The format of the name was node--. Where type was either application, backup, jenkins, gke, prod, staging, worker, www, build, redis, or runner. Maybe some others too. The number seemed to be 5 randomÂ digits.

Some of the instances were ephemeral. They all had delete protection enabled. I checked the details of a few of them and noticed some scripts that included references toÂ Monero.

So I guess a Monero mining bot was being setÂ up.

The logs showed that GKE and networking resources had also been requested, but the account which the stolen credentials belonged to didnâ€™t have the necessary permissions. Our project also maxed out its quota of compute instances in multiple regions andÂ zones.

Remediation

I deleted the account that had been leaked, and began quantifying the damage. I wanted to know exactly what permissions the key had, which resources could be created, and could the leaked account be used to create other accounts? No, itÂ canâ€™t.

After looking around and becoming confident that it was only 195 compute instances with disks and delete protection that had been created, in regions and zones across the globe, I began to remove them. No other resources had beenÂ provisioned.

It took me 10 minutes and some googling to create the followingÂ workflow:

  1. Get all the compute instances and dump them into a file. I expected to run a script that iterated through the file line by line, setting variables based on the content of the current line: gcloud compute instances list --format 'csv[no-heading](name, zone)' > names.txt

  2. In Vim, find the rows that contain the instances that I donâ€™t want to delete, and remove these from the file. There are a handful of compute instances I want to keep, and 195 that I want to remove. :v/node- shows any rows that donâ€™t includeÂ â€œnode-â€

  3. Loop through the file and for each row, which contains the instance name and itsÂ zone,

    • Remove deleteÂ protection
    • Delete theÂ instance
while IFS=, read -r name zone
  do gcloud compute instances update $name --zone $zone --no-deletion-protection \
  && gcloud compute instances delete $name --zone $zone --quiet
done < names.txt

The --quiet flag is necessary because otherwise gcloud will ask me to confirm that I want to delete the instanceÂ otherwise.

Questions

Iâ€™m surprised by the speed with which the attacker found the leaked credentials. The repo did not belong to the clients account but my own, and I assume that my account is obscure enough to not be on any interesting lists. If my account is being scanned every few minutes, presumably all accounts are being scannedÂ regularly.

How many resources are required to do that? I guess if one of these attacks works you can use the stolen compute to scan more repositories for more leaked credentials. Itâ€™s easy to imagine scenarios where large corporations that are already running complicated cloud infrastructure deployments wouldnâ€™t notice a few (200?) unauthorized compute instancesÂ running.

Study

  • Service accounts on Google CloudÂ Platform.
  • AnsibleÂ videos.
  • SSH crashÂ course.
  • Vagrant crashÂ course.
  • IFS= syntaxÂ explanation.

Comments

There was some useful discussion about this article onÂ Lobste.rs.

entry.title: Ansible
entry.content:
Background

Iâ€™ve been spending a lot of time lately working on nodes for various blockchain projects (Polkadot, Cardano, Tron, Binance Chain, Ethereum, â€¦). The rosetta api spec is super interesting, but like most things in crypto the documentation is sometimes wrong or incomplete and there are bugs and undocumentedÂ features.

Each of the nodes runs on a separate server, and we typically have one node for mainnet and another for testnet. Iâ€™m working across mutiple servers, doing difficult stuff, and I want it to be as easy asÂ possible.

I need to reduce friction and cognitiveÂ load.

Accessing the servers is easy - I use Tmux with the continuum and resurrect plugins and maintain different sessions for each type of server. This makes accessing multiple servers during the same work day really simple and effortless. But working on the servers is stillÂ awkward.

On my dev machine I have zsh with syntax highlighting, command completion, and various tools, like z to make navigation supper easy. I also have a lot of aliases defined. E.g. .. â†’ cd ... Working on a remote server should be as convenient and familiar as working on my local machine, so I want to find a way to configure a server the same way as my laptop, and I want to do it automatically so that it can be done many times, with no additionalÂ effort.

Ansible

Ansible seems to be popularÂ because:

  1. Itâ€™sÂ free
  2. Itâ€™s got all the features and capabilities youâ€™re going toÂ need
  3. Itâ€™s agentless - you donâ€™t need to install anything on the machine you want to control - you can use Ansible with anything that you can sshÂ into.

I used the following resources to getÂ started:

  • This useful video gave me some orientation and helped me figure out what I was aiming for and how to get started. Before watching it, I didnâ€™t know â€œwhich way wasÂ upâ€.

  • This blog post showed me how to create an inventory using the gcp_compute plugin.

  • I spent a lot of time being unnecessarily confused about service accounts. I guess until you have 1 success at understanding something you donâ€™t know if youâ€™ve misunderstood by a little or aÂ lot.

  • Once you have an inventory of servers that you want to connect to, you still need to specify (and prepare for) how you will connect to them. Iâ€™d hoped that the gcp_compute plugin would do some heavy lifting for me in this step, but it seems not. It can do lots of useful stuff like creating instances and specifying disk space and networks, but it wonâ€™t really help you ssh into an instance. No matterÂ thoughâ€¦

  • This blog post turned out to be just what I needed. I found it at the beginning of my search when I was trying to create an inventory, and discarded it as almost useful. Turns out that OS Login is the best way to ssh into a GCE instance and once youâ€™ve got your inventory taken care of, this blog post reallyÂ helps.

When I was installing python modules, I had some errors about pyenv shims being incorrect. The scripts were looking for versions that werenâ€™t present. Running pyenv reshash fixed it. Kind of magically, butÂ annoying.

Setting up a service account and giving it the correct permissions took more time and was more confusing than anything to do withÂ Ansible.

I found this blog post about setting up vim for yml files.

The preferred way to install ansible on Mac is using pip.

When you use OS Login the username you have when you ssh into the compute instance will change. This SO question explainsÂ why.

  • ansible-config view|list|dump
  • ansible-inventory -i inventory.compute.gcp.yml --graph
  • ansible -i inventory.compute.gcp.yml all -m ping

entry.title: Over-Engineering thisÂ blog
entry.content:
Over the last few weeks Iâ€™ve spent an unreasonable amount of time and energy making unnecessary improvements to thisÂ blog.

Some of these improvementsÂ are:

  1. Adding keyboard shortcuts (type ? to find outÂ which).
  2. Implementing, then reimplementing, and then optimizing client side fuzzyÂ search.
  3. Using src-set to serve responsive images (Image-Process).
  4. Lazy loading images to make this site loadÂ faster.
  5. Compressing page files using brotli and also gzip (Precompress).
  6. Trying (and ultimately failing) to avoid a â€œwhite flashâ€ when dark mode is chosen and a new page loads (Github discussion).

entry.title: FuseÂ Search
entry.content:
Adding search made the site feel faster and moreÂ accessible

Iâ€™ve reimplemented search on this site using fuse.js instead of tinySearch. You can read about how I implemented tinysearch here.

When I first implemented search I was surprised how much faster and more accessible the site began to feel. I could quickly access any content by typing a few words, I didnâ€™t need to scroll or follow a link.1

This means I can find content without having to think about how to get there - I donâ€™t need to break my flow or concentration. It might sound like a trivially small consideration, but lowering friction or cognitive load in small ways can make the difference between using or not using something when youâ€™re already working hard or concentrating on somethingÂ else.

For example, if I want to look up my notes about using the nohup command, I can quickly go to the site, type / (the keyboard shortcut for search), type â€œnohupâ€ and hit enter. This is all muscle-memory level impulses. I donâ€™t need to think about the content, think about its category or when I posted it, then scroll down and scan a list, or use a mouse to click on intermediate links. Win. Working at the speed of thought rather than the speed of input is a bigÂ deal.

Why I switched from tinySearch toÂ Fuse.js

Before implementing fuse.js, this site had a search feature powered by TinySearch. I wouldnâ€™t have had enough knowledge to implement fuse.js if I hadnâ€™t already learnt some JavaScript whilst setting-upÂ tinySearch.

TinySearch had an example for Pelican Blogs, and a simple and clear readme. By using tinySearch first I saw an example of how to build the JSON array that becomes the search index, and how to implement the javascript thatâ€™s required for client sideÂ search.

Also, in the course of developing and over-engineering this blog Iâ€™ve become much more proficient and comfortable with JavaScript (and jQuery) inÂ general.

Fuse.js is really quite simple to set up once youâ€™re familiar with JavaScript. Itâ€™s much more flexible than tinySearch; you can choose search weights for different fields, accuracy thresholds, and some parameters for the fuzzy searchÂ algorithm.

The general approach is to instantiate an instance of Fuse by calling Fuse with a JSON array for it to parse, along with some options. You then give the instance a string and get back an array of results which you can do whatever you wantÂ with.

The accuracy of the search results is higher with fuse.js and the speed is still acceptable. I did have to do some optimization of the search index that Fuse generates,Â though.

Optimizing the searchÂ index

The â€œnormalâ€ search index that Fuse uses to return results is a JSON array of all the content of all the articles that you want to be able to search. You can generate it using a jinja template or any other way you want. (There simply needs to be a JSON array that the browser downloads and does a fuzzy search on). This gave me a file that was about 4MB. Once I asked Fuse to search the complete text of each article (not just the default first 600 chars, iirc) then speed reallyÂ suffered.

I optimized the index file in the following threeÂ ways:

  1. Removed any non-words. Some of my articles are jupyter notebooks that have been converted to articles (the plugin to do this is one of the reasons why I began using Pelican). When the index is built, lots of code and html gets included, which isnâ€™t helpful. Any â€œwordsâ€ that are more than 20 chars I justÂ delete.

  2. Removed the 150 most common words. Any word that is in many articles is not useful for distinguishing between different articles, so they can be deleted from the index. They donâ€™t add any meaning. I wrote a short pipeline of shell commands using tr, sort, uiq to generate a file with a list of the most common words. I then wrote a python script to update the original search index by removing all the commonÂ words.

  3. Shortened any long words by only keeping the first 12 characters. If a word was 15 characters long, I simply removed that last 3 chars. I figured this would work fine because matching the first 12 characters would already be quite unique and give a goodÂ result.

Doing these 3 optimizations reduced the file size by about 90%. Compressing the JSON using gzip or brotli makes the files even smaller, and now the amount of data transferred to the client seems reasonably small. (This is a static site, and therefore search has to happen clientÂ side.)

The browser would still begin to lag as the search string length increased. It takes more time to search for a 10 character string than for a 5 character string, and initially fuse was doing a search every time a character wasÂ typed.

I wanted the site to feel as fast as possible and thought that if search was paused whilst typing and occurred a short time after the last key was pressed this would be an improvement. I added a short delay of 200ms to the function call, and typing during the delay time resets the time. This reduced the lag and made the search tool feel responsive. I learnt that this is calledÂ â€œdebouncingâ€.

There was some further complexity when I wanted to debounce characters used for searching, but not the navigation or keyboard shortcuts. Getting the debounce function to only run on some key presses was surprisingly complex. It taught me a lot of JavaScript though, and itâ€™s satisfying to have made a useful userÂ interface.

  1. It also immediately gave me the idea to add keyboard shortcuts. Type ? to see whatÂ happened â†©

__call__()

In Python, every time you call a function or method such as my_function() or my_class.my_method() the interpreter will replace the ( with .__call__(

>>> def my_function(x):
>>>    return x+1

>>> my_function.__call__(2)

class Prefixer:

>>> simonsays = Prefixer("Simon says: ")
>>> simonsays("jump up high!")

Every time you call a function or method, youâ€™re really just calling a built in __call__ method.

There should be one, and preferably only one, obvious way to doÂ something

Itâ€™s in the â€˜zen of Pythonâ€™, which is a set of guidelines that help make design decisions. Itâ€™s a choice that Python made, and other languages do itÂ differently.

There are different levels to languages and this applies more to the idiom level than the design pattern level. It applies even less at the architectural level where there can be several equally good ways of organizing business logic and dataÂ representations.

Perl has the â€œTMTOWTDIâ€ (tim towtdi) principle - â€œThereâ€™s More Than One Way To Do Itâ€. Perlâ€™s philosophy is to give users more than one way to doÂ something.

But searching a static site must be quite a common need and googling for alternatives gave me a few choices. I went with Tiny Search because it seemed to do what I needed and was easy to setup. Thereâ€™s even an example for PelicanÂ blogs.

Either way, after checking the projectâ€™s issues on Github I found an issue that matched my problem perfectly. The solution is to increase the tiny_magic variable at buildÂ time.

entry.title: Cardano: GeneratingÂ Addresses
entry.content:
If many different customers are to deposit or send ADA (The unit of currency on the Cardano blockchain) to a Cardano node, it will be necessary to determine which customer is responsible for each transaction so that the correct customer account can beÂ updated.

As with many things involving blockchains, this initially seemed like a simple requirement but involved several hours ofÂ work.

Cardano wallets are generated using a parameter called ADDRESS_POOL_GAP. The default value is 20, and is the number of unused addresses that the node will generate and return to a client using the REST API. If one of the addresses is used, the node will automatically generate another so that there are always 20 unusedÂ addresses.

This is probably very convenient for personal use. If I want someone to send me some funds, I can make a simple api call using cURL and get a fresh address. But if you are running a service, weather its e-commerce or a financial service, its not really good enough. Some advice on the forums says to generate a wallet with a very large ADDRESS_POOL_GAP value such as 10,000 and just generate a new wallet when you run out of fresh addresses, but it still feels like aÂ compromise.

But lets explain our situation in more detail first. If a customer wants to send us some ADA, we want to give them a fresh address thatâ€™s never been used before and that only they have. Then we know that any funds that arrive to that address are from a particular customer. However we donâ€™t know if the customer will actually use the address and transfer any funds. The address might remain unused or it might not. Nevertheless, that address is now reserved for them, and no one else can useÂ it.

In this way, we might need to generate and maintain a list of thousands of addresses that are never used. Using ADDRESS_POOL_GAP for this seems like a badÂ solution.

Fortunately, Cardano-Addresses has the answer, albeit in a fairly convoluted and obscured form. If you have the mnemonic that was used to generate a wallet originally, you can generate 2^31 unique addresses likeÂ so:

Clone the repo and build the dockerÂ image:

git clone https://github.com/input-output-hk/cardano-wallet 
docker build -t cardano-address .

Get the mnemonic and generate a file containing a list of space separated words on oneÂ row.

Run theÂ following:

export increment=0
((increment=increment+1)) && cat mnumonic.txt | docker run --rm -i cardano-address key from-recovery-phrase Shelley | docker run --rm -i cardano-address key child 1852H/1815H/0H/0/$increment | docker run --rm -i cardano-address key public --with-chain-code  | docker run --rm -i cardano-address address payment --network-tag testnet > payment.addr && cat payment.addr ;echo

entry.title: nohup and BackgroundÂ Processes
entry.content:
Stop stuff fromÂ stopping

If you run a command in a terminal session and the terminal session is disconnected, the processes running in it will also beÂ terminated.

I discovered this when I was trying to download a ~500gb database overnight. I logged in the next morning expecting to see a completed download, but found I only had half theÂ file.

Use nohup to ignore HUP signals

One solution to this seems to be to use nohup, a command that ignores the HUP signal. It stops your programme from stopping if the terminal session its running in isÂ stopped.

By convention, the HUP signal is the method used by a terminal to warn dependent processes that it is about toÂ logout.

You probably want to run nohup in the background. You might want to prevent it from creating nohup.out.

Close or redirect fd0 -Â fd2

On Linux, nohup automatically closes stdin. If youâ€™re using MacOS or BSD this doesnâ€™t automatically happen, so you might want to redirect it yourself. This is because if a background process tries to read anything from stdin then it will pause itself whilst it waits for you to bring it to the foreground and type some input. This is probably a waste ofÂ time.

If nohup detects that you have redirected stdout and stderr then it wonâ€™t create nohup.out.

As with all commands, if you put & at the end of the command, it will run in the background. You can bring it to the foreground by running fg, or see a list of jobs by running jobs.

If you redirect input to /dev/null () you will stop the program from receiving keyboard (stdin) input, but you wonâ€™t prevent it from accessing the terminal directly. Also you havenâ€™t removed the program from the shellâ€™s processÂ group.

Stopping signals using disown

If you want to remove a program from the shellâ€™s process group, then immediately after youâ€™ve run the command to start your programme, run disown with no arguments. This will make the background process no longer associated with the shell job and it wont have any signals forwarded to it by theÂ shell.

A disowned process gets nothing (no signals) sent to it by the shell. But without a nohup it will still be sent a HUP signal sent via other means, such as a manual kill command.

A nohuped process will ignore any and all HUP signal, no matter how they areÂ sent.

Source

UpdateÂ (2021-03-31):

Use w to see who is logged in and what they are doing. Itâ€™s summary of every user logged into a computer, what each user is currently doing, and the load all the currentÂ activity.

Itâ€™s a combination of who, uptime, and ps -a.

ProcessÂ Groups

A collection of one or more processes. Itâ€™s used to control the distribution of a signal. When a signal is directed to a process group, the signal is delivered to each process that is a member of theÂ group.

Sessions

A collection of one or more process groups. A process may not create a process group that belongs to another session. A process is not permitted to join a process group that is a member of another session. A process is not permitted to migrate from one session toÂ another.

entry.title: File Descriptors andÂ /dev/null
entry.content:
/dev/null

In Linux everything is a file, including virtual devices like keyboards. Processes (programmes) can request access to or from theseÂ devices.

The only difference between these virtual device â€œfilesâ€ and real files, is that for a virtual device the OS generates the data that goes into the file, instead of reading the data fromÂ storage.

/dev/null is a virtual device that looks like a file and is used to write output into a black hole that is discarded, lost forever and never seen. It isnâ€™t written to theÂ terminal.

FileÂ Descriptors

File descriptors are integer values assigned to aÂ file.

  • stdin has a file descriptor ofÂ 0
  • stdout has a file descriptor ofÂ 1
  • stderr has a file descriptor ofÂ 2

Two outputs are generated whenever a CLI is run stdout and stderr. By default, both these data streams are associated with the terminal. You can use file descriptors to redirectÂ them.

If a command exits successfully, the exit status isÂ 0.

If it exits unsuccessfully, the exit status will be somethingÂ else.

If you donâ€™t specify which file descriptor you want to use, bash will use stdout byÂ default.

The following redirects stdout away from the terminal and into /dev/null.

$ echo â€œHello Worldâ€ > log.txt

This will redirect stderr into aÂ file:

$ asdfadsa 2> error.txt

If you run a command that generates lots of error messages along with â€œgoodâ€ messages, you can redirect all the error messages (stderr) into /dev/null so that you can only see the useful stdout messages.Â e.g.:

$ grep -r hello /sys/ 2> /dev/null

If you want to run a command and only see the errors, (stderr) then you can filter out all the stdout by redirecting the stdout messages to /dev/null:

$ ping google.com 1> /dev/null

Redirect all output into /dev/null if you want a command to runÂ quietly,

Redirect all the output. The command below redirects stdout to /dev/null (the default file descriptor is 1 if it isnâ€™t specified) and then redirects file descriptor 2 into file descriptorÂ 1.

$ grep -r hello /sys/ > /dev/null 2>&1

Read input from a file instead of theÂ terminal

0

Direct stderr to append to a particularÂ file

2>>logfile

Combining fileÂ descriptors

2>&1 means send stderr wherever stdout is going. This means that youâ€™ve combined stdout and stderr into one data stream and you canâ€™t separate them anymore. It also means you can pipe stderr the same as you can stdout.

Input

You can redirect stdin similarly. If you run then if the program attempt to read from stdin then it will getÂ end-of-file.

The merge (or redirect) syntax (for example <&2) wonâ€™t work, because you can only redirect in the sameÂ direction.

entry.title: Cardano: Running a fullÂ node
entry.content:
I recently deployed a Cardano node on Google Cloud Platform and used its API to create and watch addresses, and makeÂ transactions.

Helpfully, Cardano make it quite simple to get up and running if you are familiar with Docker-Compose, and know where to look, and what questions toÂ ask.

Table of Contents
  • DockerÂ Compose
  • CardanoÂ wallet
  • Cardano-CLI
  • REST API
  • SurprisingÂ things

DockerÂ Compose

The Cardano Wallet repo1 contains almost all you need to get started. The command to runÂ is:

NETWORK=testnet docker-compose up -d

This does a couple of things forÂ you:

  1. Creates a Cardano node and begins syncing with theÂ network
  2. Creates a Cardano WalletÂ instance
  3. Creates all the required dataÂ volumes
  4. Maps the ports required to make APIÂ calls.

Running docker ps should show that two containers are running, cardano-node and cardano-wallet.

CardanoÂ wallet

In order to run cardano-wallet commands (not using the API, but directly on the node) youâ€™ll need to docker exec into the container likeÂ this:

sudo docker exec -it cardano-wallet_cardano-wallet_1 sh

Then you can run commandsÂ like:

cardano-wallet network information

Cardano-CLI

Similarly, if you want to use the cardano-cli programme, exec into the cardano-wallet container:

sudo docker exec -it cardano-wallet_cardano-node_1 sh 

cardano-cli â€”version

REST API

Perhaps you wont need to do this though because once the containers are up and running and online, you can use the REST API to monitor the node, make transactions, and watch addresses.2

For example, a good test to see if the node is ok is toÂ run 

curl http://localhost:8090/v2/network/information

Addresses on Cardano need to be BIP39 compliant, and before you can use the REST API to create the address you will need to have already generated the keys and the mnemonic. This can be done using various other tools (web page, python) and the results put into a JSON file according to the APIÂ spec.

SurprisingÂ things

Cardano requires that addresses are created sequentially and instead of allowing the user to generate them ad-hoc, the node by default will manage the creation of addresses of each wallet.3

The value of ADDRESS_POOL_GAP sets the number of unused addresses in each wallet. By default this is 20. When an address is used, the node will automatically generate a new unused address for the wallet, so that there is always a pool of 20 unusedÂ addresses.

entry.title: Notes From An Interview With GeoffreyÂ Hinton
entry.content:
1. Read the literature, but donâ€™t read too much ofÂ it.

  2. Trust your intuitions, because if you donâ€™t trust them then thereâ€™s noÂ point

  3. â€˜This person is either drunk or stupidâ€˜ - feedback on one of his papers that went on to becomeÂ significant

  4. For creative researchers; read a bit of the literature and notice something that you think everybody is doing wrong. (I guess GH is contrarian in thisÂ sense)

  5. Look for a problem that doesnâ€™t feel right. Then figure out how to do itÂ right.

  6. When people tell you that your (contrarian) approach is just no good, just keep atÂ it.

  7. Either your intuitions are good or theyâ€™re not. If they are good then you should follow them and you will eventually be successful. If they are bad then it doesnâ€™t matter what youÂ do.

  8. You might as well trust yourÂ intuitions.

  9. When you try to replicate a published paper you discover all the little tricks needed to make itÂ work.

  10. Never stopÂ programming.

  11. If you give a student something to do and they are a bad student then theyâ€™ll come back and say it didnâ€™t work. Theyâ€™ll say this because of some little decision they made which they didnâ€™t realise was crucial. But if you give it to a good student, you can give them anything and they will come back and say itÂ works

  12. Read enough so that you start developing intuitions, and then trust your intuitions and go for it! - Donâ€™t be too worried if everybody else says itsÂ nonsense.

  13. If you think itâ€™s a really good idea, and others tell you its complete nonsense, then you know you are really ontoÂ something!

    One example of this is when Ramford and I first came up with variational methods, I sent a mail explaining it to a former student, who showed it to his colleagues. He told me that they said â€˜Either this guy is drunk or he is just stupidâ€™. They really really thought is wasÂ nonsense.

    Maybe that is partly because of how i explained it - I explained it in intuitive terms, but when you have what you think is a good idea and other people think it is complete rubbish, that is the sign of a really goodÂ idea.

  14. See if you can find an advisor who has beliefs similar to your own, because if you work on stuff that your adviser feels deeply about, then youâ€™ll get a lot of good advice and time fromÂ them.

  15. Read enough so that you can trust yourÂ intuitions

entry.title: Notes From â€œPowerfulÂ Pythonâ€
entry.content:
The parts of Aaron Maxwellâ€™s Power Python newsletter that I donâ€™t want toÂ forget:

Table of Contents
  • EmergentÂ Abstractions
  • Practioner, Engineer,Â Scientist
  • SentinelÂ Values
  • Levels of PythonÂ Code
  • ReadÂ PEPs

EmergentÂ Abstractions

Get used to expecting and letting abstractions emerge from projects. If you find yourself repeatedly solving similar problems in similar ways, what can you do that will simplify the code and the implementation1?

Is it a couple of convenience methods on some helperÂ class?

The below code snippet gives you three ways of instantiating the twitter APIÂ client:

  1. A generic â€œnormalâ€Â way
  2. A specialized way that looks for certain environmentÂ variables
  3. A specialized way that looks for a configurationÂ file
import os # so you can get the environment variables
import twitter # https://pypi.org/project/python-twitter/

class ApiClient:
    def __init__(self, consumer_key, consumer_secret,
                 access_token_key, access_token_secret):
        self.api = twitter.Api(
            consumer_key,
            consumer_secret,
            access_token_key,
            access_token_secret)

    @classmethod
    def from_environ(cls):
        return cls(
            os.environ['TWITTER_CONSUMER_KEY'],
            os.environ['TWITTER_CONSUMER_SECRET'],
            os.environ['TWITTER_ACCESS_TOKEN_KEY'],
            os.environ['TWITTER_ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET'])

    @classmethod
    def from_config_file(cls, path):
        with open(path) as config_file:
            # ...
            return cls(...)

    # ...

Practioner, Engineer,Â Scientist

  1. Practioner - You can use a thing (a framework, aÂ tool)
  2. Engineer - You can use a thing and if you needed to, you could recreateÂ it
  3. Scientist - You can create frameworks and paradigms that have never existedÂ before

Aim for the engineerÂ level.

SentinelÂ Values

Instead of setting your sentinel value to something that is not quite impossible, like None or "None" set it to object()

This is better because it creates a unique instance of the object class and there can be no ambiguity about where it cameÂ from.

  • A sentinel value is a value you can set a variableÂ to.
  • Itâ€™s special because it differs from all other legal or possible values that the variable couldÂ have.
  • Itâ€™s used as a signal or as a canary that something hasÂ happened.

Levels of PythonÂ Code

  1. Syntax - understand what indentation is important, sometimes you need parenthesis,Â etc
  2. Idiom - the building blocks of a program. â€œParagraphsâ€ of code that follow common patterns, like for loops, or contextÂ managers.
  3. Design Pattern - Less well defined that Idioms, but more useful. - Creational Patterns, like factories - Structural Patterns, like Adapters or Proxies - Behavioural Patterns, like Visitor or Strategy These tend to be the same across differentÂ languages.
  4. Architectural - the large-scale structure of your software system. The language itself doesnâ€™t make a lot of difference, an application would have the same architecture whether it is written in Python or Java. The interface between different components would be different, but the â€œorgansâ€ of the body would essentially be theÂ same.

ReadÂ PEPs

A Python Enhancement Proposal is a document thatâ€™s written to propose a new feature ofÂ Python.

It fully details the proposed feature, the arguments for and against it, and lots of sampleÂ code.

If the PEP is accepted into a future version of Python, the PEP becomes the authoritative document for that feature and how to useÂ it.

PEPs tend to be written by the best programmers in the world, so hang out withÂ them.

entry.title: Mental Models I Used ToÂ Use
entry.content:
The rules1 and mental models that helped me succeed in one season or phase of life may not be the best for the nextÂ phase.

Here is a list of a few mental models I remember being concious of in previous years. Probably Iâ€™ve already forgottenÂ some.

  1. Always ask â€œwhyâ€¦â€. Be obsessive about this. Itâ€™s going to make things harder for a while before things get easier. Youâ€™ll find difficult answers that you otherwise wouldnâ€™t. If youâ€™re only concerned with the present then its true that ignorance is bliss, but otherwise itâ€™s aÂ liability.

  2. â€œWhat ifâ€¦â€ is another good question to ask aÂ lot.

  3. Adapt to the situation, donâ€™t make it adapt to you if you have any choice. Be kind of like water, going around things and through the gaps. Look for the edges and the gaps, the parts that arenâ€™t wellÂ known.

  4. Let people talk as much as they want to. Shut up and listen. If they mean you harm or donâ€™t respect you then itâ€™ll become more obvious the more they keep talking. If they mean you well or theyâ€™re saying something useful, you will benefit more from letting them talkÂ more.

  5. Inversion - it can be hard to know if you should do something, but how would you feel if you didnâ€™t do it, or if it didnâ€™tÂ happen?

  6. Regrets are inevitable, everyone has them. Same as making mistakes. Let your regrets be for things that you did do, and not what you didnâ€™tÂ do.

  7. If you are willing to try something, fail at it, and still be glad that you tried, then you should almost definitely do it. Commit to it and enjoy the experience! Donâ€™t be scared, or at least, be scared and optimistic and happy2.

  8. There is beauty and luxury in being in such a bad spot that you are backed into a corner with seemingly no way out. Things become black and white, instead of shades of gray, and that will make priorities and options much clearer. You are likely to work very efficiently and effectively in this scenario, and you will learn important things aboutÂ yourself.

    Now that Iâ€™m older and I have responsibilities, I canâ€™t ever let things become so bad that a situation becomes black and white. I have to navigate a world of grays. If they do become black and white, Iâ€™ll already have a long list ofÂ failings.

    When I was younger, things were more fragile. My resources were smaller and things could quickly flip from good to bad. Enjoy the few benefits that a situation like that gives, because (hopefully) once its gone its gone forÂ good.

  9. The best way to solve a problem is to prevent it from occurring in the first place. Succeeding at this will bring its ownÂ challenges.

  10. Take responsibility for things you are not responsible for, kind of. Do it deliberately and for your own benefit, but donâ€™t forget that you are only pretending that itâ€™s yourÂ responsibility.

    If you do this, you will force yourself to understand a situation more deeply and from other peoples perspectives. This will let you learn faster and help you in future. Keep this at arms length though - itâ€™s make-believe and you need to be able to switch it on and off. Itâ€™s a toy for you to play with. This seems to be what â€œextreme responsibilityâ€Â is.

I think its important to have mental models that youâ€™re comfortable with, because it lets you make decisions quickly and consistently. But understand that the map is not the territory, and these are just tools in aÂ toolbox.

  2. Courage isnâ€™t the absence of fear. Itâ€™s being scared and doing the right thingÂ anyway. â†©

entry.title: Whatâ€™s So Different AboutÂ Now
entry.content:
I think we are less aware of our ignorance than previous generations. It is easy to implicitly assume that all useful information is available to us, and that we are therefore more informed than we reallyÂ are.

I think this is because the internet has made information more accessible and global air travel have made the world feelÂ smaller.

Whilst an individual would hopefully never pretend to know everything, I think its easy to assume that the right information exists and is being used by the people to whom it isÂ relevant.

But the accessibility of all information has put us in a situation similar to information scarcity. We still need to actively search for the information we want, because the information that comes to us easily or for free is not equal to what we find when we applyÂ effort.

I can easily have so many short pieces of news or information that I am always slightly overwhelmed. The pace of modern communications encourages me to never slow down enough to form my own questions or frame my own arguments. I can always find an answer to my questions, but when was the last time I checked that whoever gave it to me wasnâ€™t going to profit fromÂ it?

entry.title: Predicting the Future using Human Nature andÂ Technology
entry.content:
Predicting the future sounds like a tough problem, but we try to do it all the time without realisingÂ it.

We predict the future when we think about how risky or scary something is, or when we think about whatâ€™s really going to change because of an announcement or press release. We try to predict the future when weâ€™re at the supermarket checkouts and we try to pick the queue that will move the fastest. I always seem to pick the wrongÂ one.

There must be a million ways of trying to predicting the future but all the good ones are models which reduce complexity and emphasise key considerations. One of them could be comparing the influence of human nature and technology on the outcome, and then comparing the event to whatâ€™s happenedÂ before.

Human nature doesnâ€™t change, so if something is driven by fear or greed then it probably doesnâ€™t matter what century it occurs in. Technology is change, and if something is enabled or prevented due to technological progress then the date isÂ important.

What is driving the scenario? Is it human nature or technology? Supermarket checkouts are mostly manual and require a couple of adults to work together, so human nature has a much bigger role on efficiency than tech. Young men will stack and pack quickly, old women will be the opposite. What types of shopping bags they have, or how they pay, or even how many items theyâ€™re buying, are probably not going to lead you to the rightÂ decision.

The same probably works for getting through airportÂ security.

entry.title: Financial Doom AndÂ Gloom
entry.content:
Financial crises seem to happen fairly regularly so they shouldnâ€™t be unexpected. But no-one seems particularly concerned about our current financial system, at the moment our attention is controlled by otherÂ threats.

Iâ€™m concerned that a lot of money has been injected into the money supply but we havenâ€™t seen any inflation. And I am concerned that the price of stocks is no longer related to the value created by the company but instead by macroÂ economics.

Itâ€™s a terrible time to be a value investor. This should be an alarming statement. Value investing should always be a decent way to make money unless markets are broken. If the price of something doesnâ€™t represent its value then a correction isÂ inevitable.

Interest rates are really low at the moment so if you have spare money and you want to make it work for you then where do you put it? Not into a bank account, because interest rates are low1, and not into government debt, because the yield is so low. It has to be stocks if you want the value of your investments to increaseÂ meaningfully.

But everyone is doing this which drives the price up, and because their price is increasing they increase evenÂ further.

I think that the main reason for concern is super low interest rates and massive increases in the money supply, but there are a couple of other factors that are alsoÂ contributing.

Itâ€™s easier than ever for retail investors to participate in the stock market, and this seems like a good idea. Democratization. However if retail investors have influence to effect prices, and they themselves can be manipulated or influenced regarding what or when they buy or sell, then that is likely a new kind of threat to financial stability. Weâ€™ve never seen social media combined with quick, cheap investment services for amateursÂ before.

Index funds are also more popular than ever2 - the efficacy of index investing relative to traditional funds that use stock pickers is very high over medium or long time horizons because index funds are much cheaper. entry.title: Debugging the more_categories plugin forÂ Pelican
entry.content:
Iâ€™ve realised that one of the plugins I use to make this blog is not working correctly. I use the more_categories pluginÂ to:

  1. addÂ subcategories
  2. assign multiple categories toÂ articles.

Subcategories arenâ€™t working and Pelican thinks each article just has categories than contain forwardÂ slashes.

In his â€œPowerful Pythonâ€ emails, Aaron Maxwell recommends looking at the source code for popular python libraries to see how really good Python is written, and how talented developers write code and solveÂ problems.

This is a good opportunity to look at the code that powers the plugin and see if if IÂ can:

  1. Understand the sourceÂ code
  2. Locate the source of theÂ problem
  3. Fix theÂ problem

I donâ€™t know if Pelican is amazingly good quality or not, I get the feeling it could do with more developer resources, but Iâ€™ve got a real reason and motivation to look at the underlying code so Iâ€™m going to give it aÂ shot.

The documentation is sparse which doesnâ€™t help, I get the impression that whoever wrote it feels like Pelican is simple and itâ€™s obvious whatâ€™s going on 1. Itâ€™s not obvious toÂ me.

PelicanÂ Plugins

Every plugin has to have a register() function, here it is for the more-categories plugin:

def register():
    signals.article_generator_context.connect(get_categories)
    signals.article_generator_finalized.connect(create_categories)

I understand the idea of signals from Django, and generators are discussed a bit in the documentation. So what else isÂ happeningâ€¦

As I write down my understanding of the plugin, Iâ€™m aware that my understanding is definitely incomplete and probably wrong. I hope that as I progress I will see the mistakes in what Iâ€™ve alreadyÂ written.

get_categories() is called first, and it takes two arguments, generator and metadata. The entire function is 3 lines so here itÂ is:

def get_categories(generator, metadata):
    categories = text_type(metadata.get('category')).split(',')
    metadata['categories'] = [Category(name, generator.settings) for name in categories]
    metadata['category'] = metadata['categories'][0]

It looks like it gets the category from the metadata for each article. Presumably by the time this function is called the articles have already been parsed and a metadata object has already been created and populated with metadata about the articles, includingÂ categories.

The first row of get_categories() splits up the categories if multiple categories are listed. metadata must be a dictionary, and there must be a metadata dict for each article, otherwise you couldnâ€™t just get get the value assoiciated with the dictionary key and then split the string onÂ commas.

This means that this function is called once for eachÂ article.

I donâ€™t know what text_type does yet. Maybe it ensures that the output is always a string. Itâ€™s imported from six which I remember seeing being a dependecy of some otherÂ packages.

.. Having checked the documentation for six it looks like I was right - it represents unicode textual data in both python2 and python3. Pelican was originally written in Python2 IÂ guess.

Next step is to write a new key-value pair to the metadata dictionary for each article. This plugin adds functionality to python by enabling categories and not just a category for each article. It seems clear that adding a categories key to the metadata dict is an obvious way to do this. The value for the categories key is a list where each item is an instance of the Category class. This class is instantiated using two arguments, name which is the string from the previous row, and generator.settings which is currently notÂ understood.

.. printing the contents of generator.settings shows that its a dictionary of all the settings. Easily assumed and good toÂ confirm.

Iâ€™ll dig into the Category class in a moment, but first lets quickly cover the last row of the function. The category attribute of the articles metadata is simply updated with the first item in the categories list (categories must be a list because it can beÂ indexed.)

classÂ Category():

This class is the only class defined by the plugin (which is only 96 lines of code). It has 6 methods, 5 of them are decorated, and it has noÂ constants.

The decorators are property [3], _name.setter [1] and URLWrapper.name.setter [1]. URLWrapper is imported from pelican.urlwrappers and I donâ€™t know what that does beyond â€œwrappingÂ URLsâ€.

@property

Decorators are functions that takes methods or functions as inputs. Using property along with setter decorators lets a class have a property assigned to it whilst ensuring that arbitrary conditions or logic is upheld. If the @property decorator is over a method called foo, then there would need to be a decorator called foo.setter on a method somewhere in theÂ class.

That doesnâ€™t seem entirely right though, because in our Category class, we have a @property decorator over a _name method, and also a @_name.setter decorator over another method called _name. But the other methods with @property decorators (slug and ancestors) do not have any associated setter decorators orÂ methods.

The setter for _name seems to create parent categories if the string containsÂ slashes:

@_name.setter
def _name(self, val):
    if '/' in val:
        parentname, val = val.rsplit('/', 1)
        self.parent = self.__class__(parentname, self.settings)
    else:
        self.parent = None
    self.shortname = val.strip()

Here, self.parent becomes an instance of the category class, that is instantiated using parentname and self.settings. This is recursive to however many levels of subcategories areÂ specified.

The ancestors and as_dict methods seem more confusing. ancestors isnâ€™t called or mentioned within the class definition, but is called from the create_categories function which is called after the get_categories function returns. I donâ€™t understand why it needs an @property decoratorÂ though.

The class inherits from URLWrapper so that is probably the next best place to lookâ€¦ Indeed, looking at the definition of URLWrapper shows that the as_dict method is overriding the definition in the baseÂ class.

  1. I guess itâ€™s the â€œcurse of knowledgeâ€ â†©

entry.title: 3 Different Types Of ProgrammingÂ Problems
entry.content:
Three categories ofÂ problem

Last year when I was creating moneybar and pippip there were a few problems that took much more effort to solve than all theÂ others.

I think I could group problems into 3 buckets, based on how much time they take to solve. Type 1 takes less than 15 minutes to solve, type 2 takes between 15 and 45 minutes to solve, and type 3 takes more than 45 minutes (usualy muchÂ more).

TypeÂ 3:

When I start learning a hard thing (like web development), almost everything is in the third bucket and itâ€™s exhausting. You need to set aside big chunks of time, you need to be focussed and undistracted, calm and wide awake, and you need to be prepared for a long arduousÂ journey.

Probably your criteria for success should be â€œam I dead?â€ because then if youâ€™re asking the question youâ€™re guaranteed to be successful and keeping morale high is necessary forÂ success.

TypeÂ 2:

Hopefully you can make good progress understanding the basics and internalizing the relevant abstractions, and your problems quickly1 become type 2 problems. They each take from 15 to 45 minutes toÂ solve.

Maybe this is because you know enough to break some big general problem into smaller problems (you are developing domain expertise) and your intuitions for how to solve the problem are becoming better so your first or second attempts are likely to be correct, rather than your fifth orÂ sixth.

Knowing how to google a problem so that you get the answer you need is also a really important skill, which requires intuiting how an English speaking expert would ask the question. This isnâ€™t trivial but I donâ€™t hear people discussing thisÂ often.

When most of my coding problems are type 2, it feels like Iâ€™m learning most efficiently and when Iâ€™m most productive2.

TypeÂ 1:

After a while, the problems that need to be solved become type 1 problems. They take less than 15 minutes to solve,Â because:

  1. All the big problems have been solved and now youâ€™ve only got smaller problems left,Â and
  2. Your intuitions are good and your expertise has increased and you know where to look for answers.3

ExceptionalÂ problems:

But there seems to be a consistent exception to this model.4 Letâ€™s be silly and call them type W problems. These are the problems that eat up far too many hours, and are tiring to solve, even when you are (in most other respects) anÂ expert.

For me, these tend to relate to blob storage solutions for web apps deployed into production. I can think of several factors why this is so, and Iâ€™ll describe the specifics beforeÂ generalising.

When a web app runs in production, the data is not stored on the web server because the things that make a web-server cheap and efficient are not the things that make a database or a file storage bucket cheap andÂ efficient.

Therefore they are stored somewhere else and you need some plumbing to join everything together. There are some abstractions involved to make this work easily and securely. However when developing locally, you are doing everything on your laptop. You have a web-server, relational database and file system all in the sameÂ place.

This is a big, fundamental, architectural difference between your development environment and your production environment. As a general rule, these are supposed to be as similar asÂ possible.

These differences make it much easier to make something that works locally but doesnâ€™t work in production, and itâ€™s very hard to test if a thing will work in production without deploying it to your staging environment, which you are likely less familiar with than your local developmentÂ setup.

Deploying to staging and debugging on staging is slower and harder than doing the same thing locally. Logging (and filtering) will likely be moreÂ important.

Solving exceptionalÂ problems

So how do you solve these problems quickly and efficiently? What is it about this problem that makes it so hard? Letâ€™s examine what makes the problem difficult toÂ solve:

  1. Iteration cycles are slow - I canâ€™t test locally, I have to deploy to staging and this takesÂ time.

  2. The problem occurs in a â€˜high frictionâ€™ environment - its difficult to dig around and figure out whatâ€™s really going on when its hidden below 3 different layers of abstraction, on a remote machine that I have limited access to via a web browser. I want to be able to dig and investigate quickly and easily using the same tools I use for writing and testing code locally. Iâ€™ve taken great efforts to set up my local development environment so that I can do this, and its stressful to switch to a different and more limited set ofÂ tools.

  3. The problem is the result of several things interacting at once, and I canâ€™t just test things one at a time. These things are probably very similar to theÂ abstractions.

    Thinking clearly, learning, buidling, solving problems, all rely on being able to separate or untangle a seemingly complex situation into its component parts so that you can figure out what causes what. If you canâ€™t isolate individual concerns or components, you have a black box that is keeping youÂ ignorant.

    In web development, customized logging is usually a good way to being isolating and exploring particularÂ components.

Having said all that, I think the best way to solve a problem is to prevent it from occurring in the first place, but Iâ€™m not good enough to figure out how to do that,Â yet.

  1. on which timescale? Life is long, does it really matter if it takes 1 week or 1 month to learn something meaningful? Momentum, and having fun, is important though. â†©
  2. from a personal growth point of view. I suppose from an employers point of view they want all problems solved fast, type 1 problems. â†©
  3. Open the right file, google the right query (and follow the link to stack overflow), make some changes, run your static type checker and linter, run your tests, and push. Done and on to the nextÂ item. â†©
  4. which is totally fine. Itâ€™s just a mental model, and the map is not the territory â†©

entry.title: Why I Want To WriteÂ Regularly
entry.content:
Iâ€™ve started writing more frequently. I want to do this because I often have thoughts which Iâ€™d like to explore and develop further but rarely do. Writing forces me to organise my thoughts and look at how substantial they really are, orÂ arenâ€™t.

There is truth in the saying that â€œto know a thing you need to be able to teach itâ€ 1 , and writing well has several similarities to teaching. Can I really copy a collection of thoughts from my head toÂ yours?

Powerful ideas are resilient and have many consequences. The older I get the more I believe that ideas matter2. They have so many subtle consequences. They are the first dominos.

I donâ€™t expect writing regularly to become a permanent habit - it doesnâ€™t need to be. But I do want to focus on it for awhile so that I become significantly better. Itâ€™s a skill that has too many benefits to beÂ ignored.

The blogs I remember most are focussed and unapologetic about their priorities. Most of them have a lot of text and do not focus on design. They make it easy to read content and donâ€™t spend time or attention on header images orÂ styling.

Before I redesigned this blog I had default settings that asked me to supply an image for each post, and for a summary, and a suggested tweet. None of it was necessary and whilst they all tried to make the blog better they ended up making it harder to write. These peripheral features added complexity and distracted from the mainÂ thing.

Theyâ€™re are still there if I want to use them but they are not set up to be used by default anymore. Theyâ€™ve been moved to the background and if I forget they exist then thatâ€™s OK - it just shows they werenâ€™t as important in practice as I thought they would be. I was probably just having fun adding new features and working out how to buildÂ them.

You Ainâ€™t Gonna Need It,Â mate.

I guess asking the right question is always necessary, but finding the right answer is only sometimes sufficient. entry.title: Using Vim with largeÂ codebases
entry.content:
I use Vim as my text editor and IDE. I like that its free, open source and customizable. Below are some of the most useful plugins and features Iâ€™ve started using this year when I was building Moneybar and learning how to useÂ Django.

Thereâ€™s a copy of my .vimrc at theÂ end.

Iâ€™m happy to invest time and effort learning how to make the most of Vim and its plugins. Iâ€™m confident that Iâ€™ll still be using it twenty years fromÂ now.

  1. Filetype plugins - if you want some settings to be active only for particular filetypes, like .py (python) or .txt (text) then create a file in ~/.vim/ftplugin/.vim.

    Vim will look in this file when it opens a buffer of the corresponding file type. Good for formatting options like line length, tab spaces, vim commands that are languageÂ specific.

    You canâ€™t activate plugins in these files though. All the plugins have to be activated in your .vimrc in the usualÂ way.

  2. janko-m/vim-test - this plugin lets you runs tests without leaving vim. You can run the test thatâ€™s nearest the cursor, or all the tests in the current buffer. Itâ€™s very customizable. I wish it could be a bit faster, but I could probably improve that myself by changing someÂ settings.

  3. dense-analysis/ale - The incredible Asyncronous Linting Engine (A.L.E) applies fixers and linters to various filetypes, when you want and how you want. Super useful for writing tidy code and catching mistakes before the code isÂ run.

  4. junegunn/fzf and junegunn/fzf.vim - It took a little getting used to at first, but now I canâ€™t imagine not using a tool like this (this could be said about so many vim-related things). Use fzf to switch between open buffers, open a new file, search for files using the filename, or search within all the files in the project for specificÂ text.

  5. majutsushi/tagbar - This plugin opens a sidebar which contains a list of of functions and classes and methods (tags). You can use it to see which methods a class contains, and jump to the part of the buffer where a tag isÂ defined.

entry.title: Using RSS
entry.content:
Updated: 10 FebÂ 2021

I found a blog post which is surprisingly similar to my thoughts on RSS feeds, but better presented and thought through. The post mentions the idea that â€œRSS is about capturing the long tail of blogs that donâ€™t post frequentlyâ€ 1.

This idea crystalised why I was so glad Iâ€™d started using RSS feeds again. If readers use RSS, then authors donâ€™t need to concern themselves with attention. This removes pressure on the author to post frequently and lets them focus on quality over quantity. News feeds and ad supported platforms have fundamentally different mechanics andÂ incentives.

With RSS I can let good quality content come to me, on its own schedule. I donâ€™t need to remember to look for it, and the authors donâ€™t need to remind me that theyÂ exist.

GoogleÂ Reader

RSS is a very effective way of having good quality information come to you. Back in 2008, I used to use Google Reader to subscribe to RSS feeds. I was an aspiring photographer back then and I remember being subscribed to around 80 blogs. Each day Iâ€™d read articles from whoever had posted something new, without needing to visit their websites or remember who they are or that Iâ€™d subscribed to their blog. The authors didnâ€™t need to optimize their output according to an opaque and changing algorithm either - they didnâ€™t need to optimize article length, tags, post frequency, image inclusion or linked content. They could write how they wanted to, which I suspect leads to higher qualityÂ content.

SocialÂ Media

A few years later Google Reader was closed down, presumably because using RSS didnâ€™t fit with Googles advertising model. I was unaware of it at the time but I imagine it sent shockwaves through blogging communities and probably upended many businesses. I mostly stopped readingÂ blogs.

Facebook was growing fast, Instagram felt new and exciting, and content was moving onto â€˜platformsâ€™, or into walled gardens. And as they kept on growing the average quality of the contentÂ decreased.

Twitter is like this now I think. There are some real diamonds to be found from time to time, but thereâ€™s a lot of mud too. Mostly its just mud, but the occasional diamond can have outsizedÂ benefits.

RSS isnâ€™t like this. I choose the contents of my â€˜news feedâ€™, and each article can be much longer than a Tweet, or a caption to a photo, or a status update. Itâ€™s hard to write well and to create an interesting or useful blog post, and that makes it harder to dilute quality with entertaining distractions. I have complete control about what content I see, and I can change it whenever I want. The process is designed aroundÂ me.

Reeder5

I used netNewsWire for a few weeks, but it couldnâ€™t sync between my laptop and phone, so I bought Reeder 5. Itâ€™s got a few unusual design patterns, but it works well and has all the features I want. Iâ€™ve been unsubscribing from email newsletters and subscribing to the RSS feedÂ instead.

It keeps my inbox quieter, and it feels good to have a â€˜separation of concernsâ€™. It makes it easier to read interesting content without beingÂ distracted.

entry.title: Notes on learningÂ Django
entry.content:
Table of Contents
  • In theÂ beginning
  • A personal financesÂ dashboard
  • LearningÂ Django
  • The best moments
    • Adding a unique identifier to an existing authenticationÂ model
    • TestingÂ code

In theÂ beginning

I came to web development via business analytics. I was working as an accountant and Excel wasnâ€™t good enough anymore, so I looked around for a way to get started and came across Jupyter Notebooks.

Notebooks are said to be a kind of â€œgateway drugâ€ to programming, and I think thatâ€™s true. Theyâ€™re the easiest and fastest way to start programming that Iâ€™ve comeÂ across.

When youâ€™re working in a notebook, its easy to get data, wrangle it, and show some results. But as soon as you can create a chart or some summary table you inevitably wonder how you can show this to people more easily, and publishing the results to a website feels like the best most general and versatileÂ solution.

Unfortunately itâ€™s also the hardest, and so begins a long series of compromises and incremental progress. Learn to use a dashboarding API, and learn to create static sites. But the end-goal, the ultimate solution, is a data driven web app, with authentication, saved user preferences, scalable performance, and automatically updated dataÂ sources.

A personal financesÂ dashboard

When I moved to the Netherlands, I wanted to use a personal finances dashboard to check weekly expenses. There wasnâ€™t a web-app that would do this (though there are a couple of apps that are trying) so I built my own dashboard. Then a few friends asked if they could use it too. They couldnâ€™t because it was just a dashboard and not a web app, but I thought this was a good reason to jump into webÂ development.

It was a much bigger task than I anticipated. (And thatâ€™s OK.)

It took several attempts and was super frustrating, I would dabble for a few weeks, do a few tutorials, and then get completely lost when I tried to do something by myself. Iâ€™d get disorientated working across many different files and trying to visualise which part of the Model-View-Controller model, or the request-response cycle I was currently workingÂ on.

I came to realisea that the mental load seems so large at the beginning because â€œweb-developmentâ€ is really a whole stack of technologies and abstractions combined (or stacked) together. Many of these have to be used together at the same time before you can see any evidence of success at all.

LearningÂ Django

I think the hardest things about Django are not actually Django. Youâ€™ll need to comfortable with classes and inheritance. Youâ€™ll also need to be comfortable with working across multiple files, and have some tools for searching across all you open buffers, or all the files in the project, at the same time. Youâ€™ll also need to be comfortable with version control (Git) and using the command line. Get familiar with stack tracesÂ too.

If youâ€™re familiar enough with all these things, so that using them doesnâ€™t feel new, but ideally feels familiar and comfortable, then I think youâ€™ll make quite quick progress withÂ Django.

Django uses the Model-View-Controller model. Models are how django maps Python objects to items in your database (oh yeah, you need to be familiar with SQL tooâ€¦), Views are where requests are processed (also Middleware) and turned into Responses, which are then combined with templates (unless your building an API). You might notice I havenâ€™t mentioned what a Controller is - get used to information feeling incomplete whilst youâ€™re learning the ropes. Itâ€™ll become clear soonÂ enough.

The bestÂ moments

The â€˜curse of knowledgeâ€™ states that once youâ€™ve learnt something you canâ€™t imagine or remember what itâ€™s like to not know it. Before that happens completely, I want to record some of the â€˜ahah!â€™ moments of â€˜learningÂ Djangoâ€™.

For context, I stopped working as a freelance data scientist in April and after a few weeks wondering if django and PostgreSQL and python was the way to go (yes it is. use boring technology), I began working full-time on what would become MoneyBar.nl. I called it â€˜myeurosâ€™ in theÂ beginning.

The learning curve felt steep. I wanted to do things â€œrightâ€ the first time because I wasnâ€™t building a toy, and although I felt that hindsight would show this to be a mistake in terms of efficiency, I did it anyway because I have a hunch that following my compulsions sometimes makes life harder in the short term and better in the longÂ term.

The best moments are usually preceded by the mostÂ frustrating.

Adding a unique identifier to an existing authenticationÂ model

I used pydannyâ€™s cookiecutter-django template. Honestly, by the time Iâ€™d gone through the quickstart process and googled the nouns in all the questions (what is Sentry, what is Celery and what is a task que, what is whitenoise, etc.) I was already tired. Play with it a few times and come back toÂ it.

Anyway, I wanted to start with authentication, because the project template has that part kind of up and rnuning for you out of the box. cookiecutter-django uses the Django Allauth package, which is awesome, and reliable, and fully featuredâ€¦ and extremely abstracted. Good luck looking at the module code and understanding it if youre not anÂ expert.

I wanted to give each user a unique ID - a UUID when they signed up. This would be used in query strings instead of usernames or incremental keys. This was so hard the first time! And it turns out its not a trivial task, not if you already have a few users in your (test) database. Sure you can reset the database and start again, but experimenting like this is fairly complex. Understanding how the python model classes (the ORM) maps to the relations in the PostgreSQL databse was complex, and if I got confused, should I try to fix it by changing python Models, or editing migrations, or working on the database directly? Getting started is one of the hardestÂ things.

After Iâ€™d figured out authentication, I started creating models for other simpler data (transactions and bank accounts I expect). This was much simpler and faster. I remember driving home one evening thinking that if I could get this far then success wasÂ inevitable.

TestingÂ code

Before long, testing each part of the app by hand when I added or changed a feature was no longer trivial. I needed to find some way of automatically creating users and checking that they could log in and accessÂ views.

I began working with pytest, and really found it hard to wrap my head around the idea accessing different parts of the app not by requests and responses but by accessing class methodsÂ directly.

I think its normal and good to code at the limit of your knowledge, where you know just enough to make a thing â€œworkâ€. But this approach falters when you want to then test what you wrote. Or at least, the measure of â€œjust enoughâ€ really changes when you require tests to be written. You donâ€™t just need to make it work, you need to understand why it works, so that you can write tests to assert that certain conditions pass and othersÂ fail.

This feels really satisfying when it works, because you have proof that you really have grasped a bigger picture. There are far fewer (relevant) black boxes when you write tests. But it also makes learning slower, at least in the short term. It means you might have two get comfortable with a handful of abstractions, when youâ€™ve already solved the problem you started with. This is frustrating, and it takes discipline to slow down, take a deeper look at the solution, and not just race on to the nextÂ feature.

entry.title: Data Science vs Web Development: Larger CodeÂ Bases
entry.content:
CodeÂ Structure

One of the most immediate and basic differences between working as a data scientist or as a web developer is the number of files the codebase is spread across and the amount of code within eachÂ file.

Web applications tend to be very modular - there are a lot of different things going on in a modern web app and generally they all need to be able to be modified or updated independently of each other. This requirement encourages modular code base architecture with the code broken down into testableÂ units.

When working on a data science project you often have a well defined and quite narrow pipe line. Each stage of a pipeline has well defined inputs andÂ outputs.

This seems to have the consequence of making data science projects tend towards a handful of files each with a substantial amount of unique (not boilerplate) code. In web development there seems to be more boilerplate, many more files spread across a tree of directories, and the average number of lines of code per file is significantlyÂ lower.

IDEÂ features

These differences mean that code organization tools and IDE features play very different roles within each industry. In web development you really need to be able to jump between different files (or buffers) quickly, and search for text across multiple files. Writing idiomatically becomes more important, and writing code within discreet testable units becomes essential so that things donâ€™t break without beingÂ noticed.

In data science, linting feels more optional, and searching for text within methods or functions outside the current module isÂ rarer.

I didnâ€™t appreciate this until I paused my work as a Data Scientist and began building non-trivial webÂ apps.
